quoteFirst: They came to high words, Swend reproaching his ally with breaking his agreement. Harald distrusted his intentions, and, at night, did not, as usual, sleep in a tent on the deck of his ship, but left a billet of wood in his place.
quoteLast: a man rowed silently up to the side of the ship, crept up to the tent, and struck so violent a blow with his axe, that it remained sticking in the wood, while the murderer retired to his boat, and rowed away in the dark.
title: Cameos from English History, from Rollo to Edward II
author: Yonge, Charlotte M. (Charlotte Mary), 1823-1901

quoteFirst: At the request of General Ostensacken, an armistice was granted from twelve till one o'clock to-day, to enable the Russians to bury their dead. There was not much firing this morning;
quoteLast: white flags were run up on the batteries on both sides, and immediately afterwards a body of Russians issued from the Redan, Flagstaff, and Malakoff batteries, and proceeded to carry off their dead; and our men, with the French, emerged from our batteries on a similar errand.

quoteFirst: From twelve o'clock at night until twelve o'clock at night is the mode of computing a day by the people of the United States, and I do not feel authorized to establish a different mode of computation for Congress. At what hour does Christmas commence? When does the first day of the year, or the first of January, commence? Is it
quoteLast: or at noon? If the first day of a year or month begins and ends at midnight, does not every other day? Congress has always acted upon the impression that the 3d of March ended at midnight; hence that setting back of clocks which we have witnessed on the 3d of March, at the termination of the short session.
title:
Thirty Years' View (Vol. 1 of 2)
or, A History of the Working of the American Government for Thirty Years, from 1820 to 1850
author: Benton, Thomas Hart, 1782-1858

quoteFirst: "I believe it, Mawruss," Abe said ironically. "But, anyhow, I'm going to ring up that oitermobile concern on Forty-sixth Street and tell 'em to send it around here
quoteLast: . Then you can go up there to the hotel, and if that Miss Atkinson ain't had her lunch yet buy it for her, Mawruss, for so sure as you stand there I bet yer that young feller, Ike, has rung up this here Max Tuchman and told him all about us going up there to take her out in an oitermobile.

quoteFirst: All through that memorable night the terror swept onward towards the north with a speed which seems almost miraculous, producing everywhere the same results.
quoteLast: a horseman, clad only in shirt and breeches, dashed by our grandfather's door, in Haverhill, twenty miles up the river.  "Turn out!  Get a musket!  Turn out!" he shouted; "the regulars are landing on Plum Island!"  "I'm glad of it," responded the old gentleman from his chamber window; "I wish they were all there, and obliged to stay there.

quoteFirst: But the citizens promptly rescued her from their hands and conveyed her to a place of safety. It was now five o'clock, and the assault had commenced
quoteLast: at noon. The French soldiers within made white flags of napkins, attached them to bayonets, and waved them from the walls. Gradually the flags of truce were seen through the smoke; the firing ceased, and the cry resounded through the crowd and was echoed along the streets of Paris, "The Bastille surrenders.
title: The French Revolution of 1789, as Viewed in the Light of Republican Institutions

quoteFirst: Alvan passed a night of dire disturbance.  The fate of the noble Genoese conspirator, slipping into still harbour water on the step from boat to boat, and borne down by the weight of his armour in the moment of the ripeness of his plot
